docs.lead_paragraph: We've achieved an unusual left-right convergence in the health care debate: Both conservatives and liberals are attacking the current version of reform as an egregious giveaway to the insurance industry. (Both sides sound an awful lot like Tim Carney, in other words.) Suddenly, it's hard to tell the difference between the right's Yuval Levin ("The bill is basically a massive subsidy to the insurers - it is not a reform of the system") and the left's Markos "Daily Kos" Moulitsas ("it's unconscionable to force people to buy a product from a private insurer that enjoys sanctioned monopoly status").
docs.abstract: Does the right-left convergence on health care make sense?
docs.snippet: Does the right-left convergence on health care make sense?

docs.lead_paragraph: Last night, by a wide margin, the House of Representatives passed a $626 billion military spending bill. And tucked deep within that legislation - on page 149 of a 161-page document - is $125 million to resurrect the Recovery Act provisions that bolstered Small Business Administration lending.

headline.main: House, With a Surprise Objection, Extends S.B.A. Stimulus Provisions

docs.abstract: The provisions, which ran out of money in late November, eliminate fees for the major S.B.A. loan guarantee programs and increase the guarantee for the 7(a) program.
docs.snippet: The provisions, which ran out of money in late November, eliminate fees for the major S.B.A. loan guarantee programs and increase the guarantee for the 7(a) program.

docs.lead_paragraph: "Ask an Expert" is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you'll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline.main: Answers About Cobra Benefits and Subsidies: Part 2

docs.abstract: Ron Pollack, the founding executive director of the nonprofit health care advocacy organization Families USA, answers reader questions about Cobra.
docs.snippet: Ron Pollack, the founding executive director of the nonprofit health care advocacy organization Families USA, answers reader questions about Cobra.

docs.lead_paragraph: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Service Employees International Union, two of the country's biggest labor organizations and strong allies of the Obama administration, have withheld their endorsements of the Senate health care bill now that the Senate has dropped the public option.

headline.main: Unions Decline to Endorse Senate Bill

docs.abstract: Two large unions say the Senate health care bill will not do enough for working families.
docs.snippet: Two large unions say the Senate health care bill will not do enough for working families.

docs.lead_paragraph: Update | 1:57 p.m. Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, told a home-state radio station on Thursday that he cannot yet support the Democrats' health care legislation because provisions regarding insurance coverage for abortions still do not meet his satisfaction and because of other outstanding concerns.
docs.abstract: Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska may be the last Democratic holdout.
docs.snippet: Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska may be the last Democratic holdout.

docs.lead_paragraph: If Senate Democrats want their version of sweeping health care legislation to carry the day, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi of California, said they have a tall order to fill: prove they have written the better bill.
docs.abstract: The House speaker is eager to see the Senate bill. Soon, please.
docs.snippet: The House speaker is eager to see the Senate bill. Soon, please.

docs.lead_paragraph: I've been looking for an opportunity to discuss Tim Carney's new book, "Obamanomics," which takes on the nexus between big government and big business, and Keith Olbermann's recent claim that "corporations, by definition, lean to the right," gives me the chance. Here's Carney's rejoinder:
docs.abstract: A look the relationship between big government and big business in Obama's Washington.
docs.snippet: A look the relationship between big government and big business in Obama's Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: It turned out the "swamp" was much deeper than anyone knew.

headline.main: Mott Haven 'Swamp' Was Deeper Than Thought

docs.abstract: The Department of Environmental Protection removed more than 625,000 gallons of stagnant water from a mile-long stretch of long-abandoned railroad tracks. The cleanup cost about $350,000.
docs.snippet: The Department of Environmental Protection removed more than 625,000 gallons of stagnant water from a mile-long stretch of long-abandoned railroad tracks. The cleanup cost about $350,000.

docs.lead_paragraph: Putting aside the theories about why Joe Lieberman is trying to hijack health care reform, let’s focus on a surprisingly good former presidential candidate — John Kerry.
docs.snippet: Putting aside the theories about why Joe Lieberman is trying to hijack health care reform, let’s focus on a surprisingly good former presidential candidate — John Kerry.

headline.main: Senator Lieberman and the Health Care Uproar
